contentrichtext.text: {{Unreferenced|date=December 2009}} [[File:ShanghaiStreet sign.jpg|thumb|[[Shanghai Street]] at Yung Shue Tau. The Yau Ma Tei [[Tin Hau temples in Hong Kong|Tin Hau Temple]] is visible in the background.]] '''Yung Shue Tau''' ([[Chinese language|Chinese:]] 榕樹頭) is the [[public square]] before [[Tin Hau Temple Complex, Yau Ma Tei|the Tin Hau Temple]] in [[Yau Ma Tei]] of [[Kowloon]] in [[Hong Kong]]. The name in Cantonese means ''the head of banyan'' indicating [[banyan]]-covered square. Yung Shue Tau is known natively but seldom written on the maps. The temple and square is deemed as the heart of the Yau Ma Tei and the remnant of fishing traditions.{{Citation needed|date=August 2007}} The square is bounded by [[Shanghai Street]], [[Public Square Street]], [[Market Street, Hong Kong|Market Street]] and the Tin Hau Temple. It splits the [[Temple Street, Hong Kong|Temple Street]] into north and south sections. The square is a gathering place for senior citizens. Many of them play [[Chinese chess]] under the banyan trees at the day time.{{Citation needed|date=August 2007}} In the evening, the surroundings are full of [[Hawker (trade)|hawkers]], [[Cantonese opera|Cantonese street opera]] and [[fortune teller]]s, and have become one of the tourist attractions, the night market of Temple Street. ==External links== {{Commons category|Yung Shue Tau}} * [http://www.panoramicearth.com/2569/Hong_Kong/Yung_Shue_Tau_Square_by_Tin_Hau_Temple Panoramic view of Yung Shue Tau] [[Category:Yau Ma Tei]] [[Category:Places in Hong Kong]]
